title: Inheritance
content:
## What is Inheritance?

Inheritance allows a class (child/derived) to inherit attributes and methods from another class (parent/base). It promotes code reuse and establishes relationships between classes.

```python
class Animal:  # Parent/Base class
    def speak(self):
        print("Some sound")

class Dog(Animal):  # Child/Derived class
    pass

dog = Dog()
dog.speak()  # Some sound (inherited)
```

## Basic Inheritance Syntax

```python
class Parent:
    def __init__(self, name):
        self.name = name
    
    def greet(self):
        print(f"Hello, I'm {self.name}")

class Child(Parent):  # Inherits from Parent
    pass

child = Child("Alice")
child.greet()  # Hello, I'm Alice
```

## Extending Parent Classes

Child classes can add new attributes and methods:

```python
class Vehicle:
    def __init__(self, brand, model):
        self.brand = brand
        self.model = model
    
    def info(self):
        return f"{self.brand} {self.model}"

class Car(Vehicle):
    def __init__(self, brand, model, doors):
        super().__init__(brand, model)  # Call parent __init__
        self.doors = doors  # New attribute
    
    def honk(self):  # New method
        print("Beep beep!")

car = Car("Toyota", "Camry", 4)
print(car.info())   # Toyota Camry (inherited)
print(car.doors)    # 4 (new attribute)
car.honk()          # Beep beep! (new method)
```

## The `super()` Function

`super()` gives access to methods of the parent class:

```python
class Person:
    def __init__(self, name, age):
        self.name = name
        self.age = age

class Student(Person):
    def __init__(self, name, age, student_id):
        super().__init__(name, age)  # Initialize parent
        self.student_id = student_id

class Teacher(Person):
    def __init__(self, name, age, subject):
        super().__init__(name, age)
        self.subject = subject

student = Student("Alice", 20, "S12345")
teacher = Teacher("Mr. Smith", 45, "Math")
```

## Method Inheritance

```python
class Shape:
    def __init__(self, color):
        self.color = color
    
    def describe(self):
        return f"A {self.color} shape"

class Circle(Shape):
    def __init__(self, color, radius):
        super().__init__(color)
        self.radius = radius
    
    def area(self):
        return 3.14159 * self.radius ** 2

circle = Circle("red", 5)
print(circle.describe())  # A red shape (inherited)
print(circle.area())      # 78.53975
```

## Checking Inheritance

```python
class Animal:
    pass

class Dog(Animal):
    pass

dog = Dog()

# isinstance checks if object is instance of class
print(isinstance(dog, Dog))     # True
print(isinstance(dog, Animal))  # True (parent class too!)

# issubclass checks class inheritance
print(issubclass(Dog, Animal))  # True
print(issubclass(Animal, Dog))  # False
```

## Inheritance Hierarchy

```python
class Animal:
    def __init__(self, name):
        self.name = name
    
    def eat(self):
        print(f"{self.name} is eating")

class Mammal(Animal):
    def nurse(self):
        print(f"{self.name} is nursing")

class Dog(Mammal):
    def bark(self):
        print(f"{self.name} says Woof!")

# Dog inherits from Mammal which inherits from Animal
dog = Dog("Buddy")
dog.eat()    # From Animal
dog.nurse()  # From Mammal
dog.bark()   # From Dog
```

## Everything Inherits from `object`

```python
class MyClass:
    pass

# Equivalent to:
class MyClass(object):
    pass

print(issubclass(MyClass, object))  # True
print(isinstance(MyClass(), object))  # True
```

## Benefits of Inheritance

| Benefit | Description |
|---------|-------------|
| Code Reuse | Share code between related classes |
| Extensibility | Add functionality without modifying parent |
| Polymorphism | Treat related objects uniformly |
| Organization | Create logical class hierarchies |

# Inheritance - Practice

class Employee:
    """Base class for all employees"""
    
    def __init__(self, name, employee_id, salary):
        self.name = name
        self.employee_id = employee_id
        self.salary = salary
    
    def get_info(self):
        return f"{self.name} (ID: {self.employee_id})"
    
    def calculate_bonus(self):
        return self.salary * 0.1  # 10% bonus

class Developer(Employee):
    """Developer with programming languages"""
    
    def __init__(self, name, employee_id, salary, languages):
        super().__init__(name, employee_id, salary)
        self.languages = languages
    
    def code(self):
        print(f"{self.name} is coding in {', '.join(self.languages)}")
    
    def calculate_bonus(self):
        # Developers get higher bonus
        return self.salary * 0.15

class Manager(Employee):
    """Manager with team members"""
    
    def __init__(self, name, employee_id, salary):
        super().__init__(name, employee_id, salary)
        self.team = []
    
    def add_team_member(self, employee):
        self.team.append(employee)
        print(f"Added {employee.name} to {self.name}'s team")
    
    def show_team(self):
        print(f"\n{self.name}'s Team:")
        for member in self.team:
            print(f"  - {member.get_info()}")
    
    def calculate_bonus(self):
        # Managers get bonus based on team size
        return self.salary * 0.12 + len(self.team) * 500

# Create employees
dev1 = Developer("Alice", "D001", 80000, ["Python", "JavaScript"])
dev2 = Developer("Bob", "D002", 75000, ["Java", "C++"])
manager = Manager("Carol", "M001", 100000)

# Use inherited methods
print(dev1.get_info())
dev1.code()

# Build team
manager.add_team_member(dev1)
manager.add_team_member(dev2)
manager.show_team()

# Calculate bonuses
print(f"\nBonuses:")
print(f"  {dev1.name}: ${dev1.calculate_bonus():,.2f}")
print(f"  {dev2.name}: ${dev2.calculate_bonus():,.2f}")
print(f"  {manager.name}: ${manager.calculate_bonus():,.2f}")
